justification: The paper states that participants played the Dictator Game (DG) to measure how much money they chose to donate to an anonymous participant, serving as a measure of their prosocial behavior.
The study presents the Trade-Off Game (TOG) as an instrument to assess preferences related to morality and prosocial behavior by framing choices as morally appropriate in different ways.

The TOG was used with different moral frames (e.g., Give -Do Good, Equalize -Avoid Bad) to empirically assess the impact of moral considerations on decision-making, supporting the morality preference hypothesis.
